themes: Loss of major arts organizations and events
Critique of funding rubrics prioritizing leadership demographics
Imbalance between private and public funding responsibilities
Underfunding and lack of advocacy for visual arts
Disproportionate support for performing arts over visual arts
Facility design favoring performance over visual arts
key_phrases: organizations like Big Medium and events like the Austin Studio Tour get killed off
the rubric for ACME's support would do well to consider the breadth of opportunity
special population metrics overly focused on leadership demographics
why private donors have left so much of the responsibility for support of the major arts to the City
funding for visual arts suffers with respect to other art forms
performing arts groups... are inherently organized and... provide focused advocacy
visual arts were shunted off to an upstairs corner in a gallery with less display wall
a balanced approach would guard against squeaky wheels getting all the grease
barriers_identified: Overemphasis on leadership demographics in funding criteria
Lack of private donor support for major arts organizations
Visual arts lack organized advocacy compared to performing arts
solutions_proposed: Adjust funding rubric to consider breadth of opportunity for artists
Require private donors to support major arts infrastructure
City funding should prioritize organizations lacking access to big donors
Handicap City support to account for differences in advocacy capacity among art forms
Fill gaps in the arts landscape rather than reinforcing already-strong sectors
Adopt a balanced approach to funding and infrastructure
